solution.text:
The spontaneity of a reaction is decided based on the total entropy change or \(\Delta_r S_ {total}\) not by \(\Delta_r S_ {sys}\)
\(\Delta_r S_ {total} = \Delta_r S_ {sys} + \Delta_r S_ {surr}\)
Also \(\Delta_r S_ {surr} = - \frac { \Delta _r H_T}{T}\)
Therefore, \(\Delta_r S_ {surr} = - \frac {- _{m}_ \times 10^3}{_{i}_}\) = \(_{{trunc(Decimal(m) * 1000 / i, 2)}}_ \frac{J}{K\;mol}\)

\(\implies \Delta_r S_ {total} = - _{l}_ + _{{trunc(Decimal(m) * 1000 / i, 2)}}_\)
\(\implies \Delta_r S_ {total} = _{{trunc((Decimal(m) * 1000 / i)-Decimal(l),2)}}_\)

Since the total entropy change for this reaction is positive, it is spontaneous.

content.text: The reaction \((A \rightarrow _{k}_ B)\) has a \(\Delta S_ {sys} = -_{l}_ \frac{J}{K\;mol}\) at _{i}_ K but is still spontaneous. Why is that? Note that \((\Delta _r H_ {_{i}_K} = - _{m}_ * 10^3 \frac{J}{mol})\)

The entropy change for the surroundings is negative
The change in Gibbs energy is positive
